articles.headline: Mormon Candidate Braces for Religion as Issue
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney expressed confidence that he could quell concerns about his faith as he runs for president.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney expressed confidence that he could quell concerns about his faith as he runs for president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 — As he begins campaigning for the Republican presidential nomination, Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, is facing a threshold issue: Will his religion — he is a Mormon — be a big obstacle to winning the White House?
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Copter Crashes Suggest Shift in Iraqi Tactics
articles.snippet: American officials say a streak of crashes strongly suggests that insurgents have changed tactics and are putting more effort into shooting down aircraft.
articles.abstract: American officials say a streak of crashes strongly suggests that insurgents have changed tactics and are putting more effort into shooting down aircraft.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Feb. 7 — With two more helicopter crashes near Baghdad, including a Marine transport crash on Wednesday that killed seven people, the number of helicopters that have gone down in Iraq over the past three weeks rose to six. American officials say the streak strongly suggests that insurgents have adapted their tactics and are now putting more effort into shooting down the aircraft.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and James Glanz

articles.headline: Home Depot Gets a Fresh Coat of Less-Glossy Paint
articles.snippet: Home Depot’s new chief  is working to return the chain to its humble retail roots and erase the perception that it has lost its focus.
articles.abstract: Home Depot’s new chief  is working to return the chain to its humble retail roots and erase the perception that it has lost its focus.
articles.lead_paragraph: For six years, it was a perk that Home Depot’s chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, could not do without: a catered lunch for his top deputies, served daily on the 22nd floor of the company’s headquarters in Atlanta.

articles.headline: Takeover Battle Ends With Sale of Big Landlord
articles.snippet: The fiercest buyout battle since 1980’s pitted two very different N.Y. financiers against each other.
articles.abstract: The fiercest buyout battle since 1980’s pitted two very different N.Y. financiers against each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Roses are red, violets are blue; I hear a rumor, is it true?”
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Terry Pristin

articles.headline: Breaking the Myth of Megapixels
articles.snippet: The myth that the more megapixels a camera has, the better the pictures, is a big fat lie.
articles.abstract: The myth that the more megapixels a camera has, the better the pictures, is a big fat lie.
articles.lead_paragraph: For an industry that’s built on science, the technology world sure has its share of myths. Thousands of people believe that forwarding a certain e-mail message to 50 friends will bring great riches, that the gigahertz rating of a computer is a good comparative speed score, or that Bill Gates once said “640K of RAM ought to be enough for anybody.”

articles.headline: Ads Made by You, in a Click
articles.snippet: Several companies are offering automated ad creation over the Internet and ad placement services that can be used to focus marketing efforts.
articles.abstract: Several companies are offering automated ad creation over the Internet and ad placement services that can be used to focus marketing efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Internet has allowed consumers to trade stocks without using high-priced brokers and travelers to book flights directly from airlines.

articles.headline: Bank Settles Shelter Suits by Investors
articles.snippet: The settlement by Deutsche Bank is a major shift in how it is dealing with the legal woes surrounding its tax shelter work.
articles.abstract: The settlement by Deutsche Bank is a major shift in how it is dealing with the legal woes surrounding its tax shelter work.

articles.headline: A380 Test Flight: 2 Bars, 15 Lavatories and 200 Reporters
articles.snippet: Airbus introduced its 519-seat double-deck airplane to 200 members of the news media in a flight over France.
articles.abstract: Airbus introduced its 519-seat double-deck airplane to 200 members of the news media in a flight over France.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOULOUSE, France, Feb. 7 — John J. Leahy, the master salesman of Airbus, was reeling off trivia as the A380 barreled down a rain-swept runway here on Wednesday, carrying 200 journalists on the first flight for the news media of this double-decker jet, the world’s largest passenger plane.
